text:
<@UCUSW7WVD> Spoken like someone who could have a great future at GitHub as an Electron Evangelist… :grin:
Seriously, these are some great suggestions! (Also a lot of work, so I totally get if <@UC2A2ARPT> has more important things to deal with.)

text: <@UC2A2ARPT> “mechanical empathy” — did you just make that up on the spot or is that already a thing? I love it.

elements.text: “mechanical empathy” — did you just make that up on the spot or is that already a thing? I love it.

text:
What you describe matches my experience on Apple platforms. Building great apps with empathy for your users is hard on any platform (the corollary to “you can write bad apps with any toolkit”), and many developers don’t care enough about that extra effort.

Even on a platform where “mechanical empathy” has a longer and stronger history, it’s shocking to see how few developers know how to use a debugger effectively and how little they know about the profiling and performance tools available to them. And let’s not even get into the less mechanical part of empathy like on-boarding, accessibility, localization, and cultural adaptation…

Don’t get me wrong, I’m not talking about junior developers that don’t have much experience yet. I’m talking about the kind of veteran developer who has shipped many major apps and they clearly know their language and libraries, but then you get to meet them and ask something about performance or get to help them debugging a potential platform bug and get to see their debugging process…

I wonder if that is a side effect of engineering culture, where programmers are often under ridiculous deadlines set by managers who don’t understand programming. For sure over time that normalizes into “It works well enough. Just ship it!”

Even on a platform where “mechanical empathy” has a longer and stronger history, it’s shocking to see how few developers know how to use a debugger effectively and how little they know about the profiling and performance tools available to them. And let’s not even get into the less mechanical part of empathy like on-boarding, accessibility, localization, and cultural adaptation…

Don’t get me wrong, I’m not talking about junior developers that don’t have much experience yet. I’m talking about the kind of veteran developer who has shipped many major apps and they clearly know their language and libraries, but then you get to meet them and ask something about performance or get to help them debugging a potential platform bug and get to see their debugging process…

I wonder if that is a side effect of engineering culture, where programmers are often under ridiculous deadlines set by managers who don’t understand programming. For sure over time that normalizes into “It works well enough. Just ship it!”

text:
Although not exactly packed with practical knowledge or actionable advice, this foreword by Kevlin Henney captures a mood that is inspiring a positive future of programming — by looking at the past in a new light: 
<https://medium.com/@kevlinhenney/legacy-reclaiming-the-word-93ec2a330ef1>

(Don’t know anything about the book. It was just the foreword that caught my attention.)

elements.text: Although not exactly packed with practical knowledge or actionable advice, this foreword by Kevlin Henney captures a mood that is inspiring a positive future of programming — by looking at the past in a new light:
(Don’t know anything about the book. It was just the foreword that caught my attention.)

text:
<@UCUSW7WVD> Well, my personal future-of-programming project is built in such a way, so when I release it that'll serve as an example. The short answer is.. any time you run an animation loop, feed information back up from the leaf nodes, letting the root loop know whether it's safe to be shut down. Then, in addition, you need any event that requires the animation loop to run to turn it back on if it's off. For me, the information I pass back up from the leaves is usually a string or symbol giving the name of the leaf node, so I can track which parts of the code still have more work to do, and which ones are done — better than just passing up `true` for more work and `false` for done.

<@U5STGTB3J> I misremember the term — it's "Mechanical Sympathy", and it's an existing thing, not a new coinage on my part.

elements.text: Well, my personal future-of-programming project is built in such a way, so when I release it that'll serve as an example. The short answer is.. any time you run an animation loop, feed information back up from the leaf nodes, letting the root loop know whether it's safe to be shut down. Then, in addition, you need any event that requires the animation loop to run to turn it back on if it's off. For me, the information I pass back up from the leaves is usually a string or symbol giving the name of the leaf node, so I can track which parts of the code still have more work to do, and which ones are done — better than just passing up
true
for more work and
false
for done.
I misremember the term — it's "Mechanical Sympathy", and it's an existing thing, not a new coinage on my part.

text:
But don't block on releasing the final product. I think I'm asking for something like <http://akkartik.name/post/four-repos> which is just building blocks for my future of programming project at <https://github.com/akkartik/mu>.

The whole project can often be totalizing, wanting to take over every last detail about how people program. An example repo is just an illustration of one small idea.

elements.text: Rich Hickey's "Simple Made Easy" talk is related, and is also recommended:

text: The Cell language (and the two presentations I just linked to) fascinate me for what they suggest about how to make programming better, and for what they imply about programming language design.

elements.text: The Cell language (and the two presentations I just linked to) fascinate me for what they suggest about how to make programming better, and for what they imply about programming language design.

text: I'm trying to use these insights to design the Curv programming language. An unsolved issue for me is, what mechanisms should be provided for data abstraction?

elements.text: I'm trying to use these insights to design the Curv programming language. An unsolved issue for me is, what mechanisms should be provided for data abstraction?

text: I've been using OOP for many years now. I now see OOP practice as a primary source of unnecessary software complexity. The Tar Pit paper provides a lot of backing for my intuition: it mentions State, and Unnecessary Data Abstraction (which is most data abstraction), as common sources of complexity.

elements.text: I've been using OOP for many years now. I now see OOP practice as a primary source of unnecessary software complexity. The Tar Pit paper provides a lot of backing for my intuition: it mentions State, and Unnecessary Data Abstraction (which is most data abstraction), as common sources of complexity.

text: The Tar Pit paper makes this amazing assertion: Power Corrupts. When I was young, I thought that I wanted programming languages to be as powerful as possible. When I first encountered Continuations in Scheme, I thought "Wow, this is really powerful!". Of course, continuations are generalized gotos, and today, I think they are a terrible idea.

elements.text: The Tar Pit paper makes this amazing assertion: Power Corrupts. When I was young, I thought that I wanted programming languages to be as powerful as possible. When I first encountered Continuations in Scheme, I thought "Wow, this is really powerful!". Of course, continuations are generalized gotos, and today, I think they are a terrible idea.

text: So now, look at the Cell data model (<http://cell-lang.net/data.html>). Note what's missing. First, there are no mutable objects, no object references, no pointers. Pointers are the GOTOs of data structures (and remember, Power Corrupts). In the Cell data model, all data is hierarchical. There are no cycles, no aliasing. This limits complexity.

elements.text: So now, look at the Cell data model (

). Note what's missing. First, there are no mutable objects, no object references, no pointers. Pointers are the GOTOs of data structures (and remember, Power Corrupts). In the Cell data model, all data is hierarchical. There are no cycles, no aliasing. This limits complexity.

text: I ought to read that paper so I can understand all this better. One thing I want to say: the documentation for Cell is excellent. How did you all find out about Cell? It seems very obscure. I can't even find the creator's name

text:
This is a more strident introduction: <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W7qMZtta9to>. I like it.

Bottom up engineering: when you have intention but don't have a way to specify it directly.
